metadata.description: Predefined cross-framework control mappings for OpenWatch unified compliance

mappings.rationale: Both controls address session lock/timeout requirements
evidence: NIST AC-11 requires session lock after period of inactivity
Both prevent unauthorized access to unattended sessions
mappings.implementation_notes: Both require configurable timeout period, typically 15 minutes or less

mappings.rationale: NIST AC-11 is more specific implementation of ISO A.9.1 access control
evidence: ISO A.9.1 covers general access control policy
NIST AC-11 provides specific session lock requirements
Session lock is a subset of broader access control
mappings.implementation_notes: NIST provides technical details, ISO provides policy framework

mappings.rationale: Both address cryptographic controls with different focus areas
evidence: NIST SC-13 covers cryptographic protection requirements
Both ensure data protection through cryptography
mappings.implementation_notes: NIST focuses on policy, CIS on technical implementation

evidence: NIST IA-5 covers authenticator management lifecycle
mappings.implementation_notes: Both require password complexity, length, and rotation policies

evidence: PCI 8.1.1 addresses user authentication for cardholder data
mappings.implementation_notes: PCI is more specific to cardholder data environment

mappings.rationale: SRG requirement derived from NIST control
evidence: Directly implements NIST AC-11 for operating systems
mappings.implementation_notes: SRG provides technical implementation of NIST policy requirement

mappings.rationale: STIG rule implements SRG requirement for RHEL 9
evidence: Platform-specific implementation of general SRG rule
mappings.implementation_notes: RHEL 9 specific commands and configuration files

mappings.rationale: FIPS cryptography requirement implements NIST cryptographic controls
mappings.implementation_notes: FIPS mode provides NIST-approved cryptographic algorithms

mappings.rationale: Both address access control but different scopes
evidence: ISO A.9.1 covers general access control policy
PCI 7.1.1 addresses cardholder data access restriction
Both implement principle of least privilege
mappings.implementation_notes: PCI more specific to payment card data, ISO covers all information assets

mappings.rationale: Both require cryptographic protection of sensitive data
evidence: PCI 3.4.1 requires encryption of cardholder data
mappings.implementation_notes: Both require encryption of data at rest and in transit

mappings.rationale: Both controls address asset inventory management
evidence: NIST CM-8 covers information system component inventory
mappings.implementation_notes: Both require automated discovery and tracking of assets

mappings.rationale: Both address software inventory and unauthorized software prevention
evidence: NIST CM-7 covers least functionality principle
mappings.implementation_notes: Both require whitelisting and software restriction policies

mappings.rationale: Both controls address baseline configuration management
evidence: Both ensure systems are securely configured
mappings.implementation_notes: Both require documented baselines and configuration monitoring

mappings.rationale: Both address audit logging and event monitoring
evidence: NIST AU-2 covers audit events definition
mappings.implementation_notes: Both require centralized logging and log retention policies

mappings.rationale: Both address secure configuration but different scopes
evidence: PCI 2.1.1 requires secure configuration for cardholder data environment
CIS 4.1 covers general secure configuration baselines
mappings.implementation_notes: PCI specific to payment processing, CIS applies broadly

nist_iso_alignment.description: NIST and ISO have strong alignment in security control objectives

srg_stig_hierarchy.description: STIG implements SRG requirements for specific platforms

cis_nist_overlap.description: CIS and NIST have significant overlap in technical controls

exceeding_compliance_patterns.description: FIPS cryptography mode exceeds CIS SHA1 prohibition requirements
exceeding_compliance_patterns.enhancement: FIPS mode automatically disables weak algorithms including SHA1
exceeding_compliance_patterns.business_value: Enhanced security posture beyond baseline requirements

exceeding_compliance_patterns.description: Enterprise session timeouts often exceed framework minimums
exceeding_compliance_patterns.business_value: Reduced exposure window for unattended sessions
